page.title: 08COACHING DAYS-WENT HILLS.
page.content: Wentbridge was disliked by the coachmen who had to drive their coaches through what was called the worst stretch of road along the A1. The approach from both north and south were very difficult, with steep descents followed immediately by a stiff climb. It was a place where accidents happened quite frequently. Eventually a cutting was made through the limestone to improve the road and make it safer. Just as this was finished, the railways took over as the main form of transport, and the coaching trade, with its many visitors, both welcome and unwelcome, ceased to pass through the village. Another important group of travellers who passed through were the drovers. The Gate Inn had enough grazing for up to 700 head of cattle, as well as room for 50 men and horses.
